docs.lead_paragraph: An estimated $5.8 billion will be spent this year in the United States to treat people infected with the AIDS virus, including those with the disease, a Federal health economist told an international meeting on AIDS here today. The figure is expected to rise to $10.4 billion in 1994. While costs of treating people with AIDS have been estimated in other analyses, the new study is the first to assess the economic effect of treating both those with AIDS and those who are infected but lack symptoms, the economist, Fred J. Hellinger, said.

headline.main: Cost of AIDS Care in U.S. Is Seen at $5.8 Billion in '91

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: "Clozapine's Price, and Value" (editorial, June 3), on the schizophrenia drug, notes that the manufacturer, Sandoz Pharmaceuticals, sells it in Europe for much less, and criticizes Sandoz's "profiteering."

headline.main: Schizophrenia Drug Not Suitable for the Homeless Mentally Ill; High Cost of Lawsuits

docs.snippet: To the Editor:   "Clozapine's Price, and Value" (editorial, June 3), on the schizophrenia drug, notes that the manufacturer, Sandoz Pharmaceuticals, sells it in Europe for much less, and criticizes Sandoz's "profiteering."

docs.lead_paragraph: IS the AIDS epidemic in the United States reaching its peak? Although only a few experts are willing to say it has, quite a number believe the question is at least worth discussing. Ten years after the first cases were recognized, the disease is still untamed and has yet to do its worst in the rest of the world. But in the United States, it could be possible in the foreseeable future to declare the deadly tide on the ebb.

headline.main: Experts Debate if AIDS Epidemic Has at Last Crested in U.S.
